title.narrative: UNICEF, Skydd av barn i väpnad konflikt, 2020-2023
UNICEF, Support to the protection of children in armed conflict, 2020-2023

description.narrative: PROGRAMME RESULTS To account for contemporary conflict contexts and to address the identified key challenges, this project will support children exiting armed forces and armed groups through a formal or informal process to receive higher quality, sustained, evidence-based reintegration services through the four following outputs: Output 1: A robust adaptable programme framework for reintegration of children exiting armed forces and groups is in place and being implemented in at least three countries. UNICEF will 1. Hold internal and external stakeholder consultations to support development of a global framework on child reintegration. 2. Develop foundational documents for a programme framework: - Outcome(s) and Output(s) that are realistic, adaptable and evidence based. - A Theory of Change for child reintegration programming based on the identified comparative advantages of UNICEF and other key partners and stakeholders. - A results framework for child reintegration that can be used across the humanitarian, development and peace nexus and in a variety of contexts, including in the context of counter-terrorism Output 2: Program practitioners have the knowledge, skills and tools to design and implement quality and coordinated programmes to prevent and respond to child recruitment and support release and reintegration of boys and girls associated with armed forces and armed groups. UNICEF and partners will pilot test and roll out Capacity Building and Programme Resource Toolkit for reintegration to children formerly associated with armed forces and armed groups in at least three countries with a special focus on girls. Output 3: High quality, community-based reintegration services are available for children disassociated from armed forces/groups and children released from arbitrary detention in the Central African Republic, Somalia, and South Sudan. UNICEF and partners will use the developed programme framework and toolkit to deliver high quality reintegration services in at least three countries. Output 4: New evidence on programme impact and monitoring and reporting on grave violations of child rights is available to inform advocacy and programme planning. UNICEF will strengthen the monitoring and reporting mechanism on grave violations of child rights and build evidence through monitoring and evaluation on CAAFAG programming.

UNICEF has applied to Sida for funding of 40 million SEK to carry out the project ”Evidence Based Prevention and Response for Children Associated with Armed Forces and Groups” during the period 2020-2023. The intervention builds on the project ”Enhancing the Protection of Children in Armed Conflict” (2017-2020, #11559) and will continue to be implemented in the Central African Republic, Somalia and South Sudan where direct support is provided to the release and reintegration of children associated with armed forces and armed groups (CAAFAG) while local and national systems are strengthened in these three contexts with possibilities to include more countries to carry the work forward through specific tools developed by UNICEF during the first phase.
The outputs aim towards: 1) A robust adaptable programme framework for reintegration of children exiting armed forces and groups is in place and being implemented in at least three countries; 2) Program practitioners have the knowledge, skills and tools to design and implement quality and coordinated programmes to prevent and respond to child recruitment and support release and reintegration of boys and girls associated with armed forces and armed groups; 3) High quality, community-based reintegration services are available for children disassociated from armed forces/groups and children released from arbitrary detention in the Central African Republic, Somalia, and South Sudan; 4) New evidence on programme impact and monitoring and reporting on grave violations of child rights is available to inform advocacy and programme planning.
The project will be implemented in the three selected countries through UNICEF’s partners and approximately 50% of the intervention budget will be forwarded to these partners.

Unicef har ansökt om projektstöd till ”Evidence Based Prevention and Response for Children Associated with Armed Forces and Groups” om 40 MSEK under åren 2020-2022. Stödet bygger på insatsen ”Enhancing the Protection of Children in Armed Conflict” (2017-2020, insatsnummer 11559) och kommer fortsatt implementeras i CAR, Somalia och Sydsudan där direkt stöd ges till frisläppande och återintegrering av barn som associerats med väpnade styrkor och grupper (CAAFAG) samtidigt som lokala och nationella system stärks i dessa tre kontexter med möjlighet att inkludera fler länder för att föra arbetet vidare genom specifika verktyg som Unicef tagit fram under första fasen. Unicef HK kommer även ta fram ett globalt program för återintegrering av barn som sträcker sig över humanitära-, utvecklings- och fredsinsatser (trippel nexus).
Projektet genomförs utifrån fyra målområden: 1) Framtagande och implementerande av robust, anpassningsbart ramverk för återintegrering av frisläppta barn från väpnade styrkor och grupper i åtminstone tre länder, 2) Berörda skyddsaktörer besitter kunskap och verktyg för att utforma och implementera samordnade program av god kvalitet för att förebygga och bemöta rekrytering av barn samt stödja frisläppande och återintegrering av flickor och pojkar som associeras med väpnade styrkor och grupper, 3) Samhällstjänster av hög kvalitet finns tillgängliga för barn som frisläppts från väpnade styrkor/grupper samt från godtyckliga anhållanden i Centralafrikanska Republiken, Somalia och Sydsudan, 4) Ny evidens om programmets långsiktiga resultat och uppföljning och rapportering av grova förbrytelser av barns rättigheter är tillgänglig för att vägleda påverkansarbete och programmering.
Programmet implementeras i de tre utvalda länderna genom Unicefs partners och a 50% av medlen vidareförmedlas till dessa.

title.narrative: Agreement between Sida and UNICEF on Evidence Based Prevention and Response for Children Associated with Armed Forces and Groups (2020-2022)
Beslut om insats, Unicef - stöd till skydd av barn i väpnad konflikt (2020-2022)

description.narrative:
This CoP covers the period 1 April 2020 to 31 December 2020 and builds on conclusions already mentioned in the completion memo for the previous programme Enhancing the Protection of Children in Armed Conflict, Contribution ID: 11559. The first progress report for the new programme, Evidence Based Prevention and Response for Children Associated with Armed Forces and Armed Groups (CAAFAG) was delivered on 25 June 2021, five days ahead of time. Achievements and results are presented under each of the four output areas both at the UNICEF HQ Programme Division as well as in the three participating countries, Central African Republic (CAR), Somalia and South Sudan. An updated results framework indicates progress as well as delays, mainly due to movement restrictions related to Covid-19 that reduced the possibility of verification missions. The report also mentions challenges and lessons learned as well as planned activities ahead both for the global team at HQ as well as for each of the country offices.
Technical and direct support for community-based reintegration was provided for 2,124 children (511 girls) who have been released from armed actors while capacity building reached 401 child protection practitioners in the three countries.
UNICEF has been able to make advancements also in developing technical tools for CAAFAG through the launch of the Technical Note on Girls Associated with Armed Forces and Armed Groups as well as the first draft CAAFAG Programme Development Toolkit and in the preparations for the field testing of the Toolkit.
Progress under the four outputs areas are included below:
1. Through efforts to bring consistency in measurement around the outcomes of UNICEF and partners CAAFAG programming, UNICEF has taken recommendations from the internal strategic stocktaking conducted in 2020 through Sidas previous support (11559) further by among others preparing for a possible collaboration with Innocenti, UNICEFs Office of Research, in 2021 to consider possible topics for study. A unified Theory of Change for CAAFAG will also be planned across the Child Protection in Humanitarian Action unit, covering both the Monitoring and Reporting Mechanism (MRM) on grave violations of child rights, as well as UNICEFs work with CAAFAG. This ToC will then be developed into a joint ToC with other organizations to develop a Global Programme on Reintegration of CAAFAG.
2. In improving capacities of governments, NGOs and community actors to prevent and respond to child recruitment and supporting their release and reintegration, the standardized tools for the case management framework on child protection were shared with government social workers and child protection NGOs in CAR with training reaching 67 participants (26 females and 41 men). In addition, national standard operating procedures were developed through the previously established Case Management Task Force and the Ministry for the Promotion of Women, Families and Protection of Children. The SOPs clarify roles and responsibilities and allow for improved coordination, oversight and support to government and NGO social workers providing response services to affected children. UNICEF also strengthened the MRM technical working group members' capacity to collect and report violations (35 females and 53 males).
In Somalia, apart from continued work and advocacy through the CAAC working group and Group of Friends of CAAC, UNICEF, Adam Smith Foundation and the Ministry of Interior and National Security developed an assessment tool enforcing the release of children to UNICEF within 72 hours and the presence of a social worker if intelligence officers interview children. UNICEF has previously reported the challenges with children associated with Al Shabaab, and this tool emphasizes children as victims of recruitment as opposed to viewing children as terrorists/criminals. Trainings also continued on including science of mindfulness and the brains neurological functions to address shocks that impact mental health and psychosocial well-being among released children.
In South Sudan, a High Level Inter-Ministerial Committee and a National Level Technical Committee were established with technical committees in nine of the ten states. A total of 240 (40 female, 200 male) members were trained on national and international legal frameworks underpinning the CAAFAG agenda.
At UNICEF HQ, the CAAFAG Task Force, established by UNICEF, Alliance for Child Protection in Humanitarian Action and Plan International-Canada during the previous project, developed a Capacity Needs and Gaps Analysis: CAAFAG Programming and finalized the launch of the Technical Note on Girls Associated with Armed Forces and Armed Groups. Planning on field testing the Programme Toolkit continued, with delays due to COVID-19.
3. Support to the release and reintegration of CAAFAG continued in the three countries. In CAR, 885 children (314 girls) received reintegration support in partnership with Vision et Développement and AFEB. Youth groups were formed, providing appropriate and marketable vocational training and income generating alternatives for released children. Based on lessons learned from the previous support, other vulnerable children and adolescents are included to reduce stigma against CAAFAG. In addition, 78 new foster families were identified and trained as well as 254 members (109 female) of the 22 community-based child protection networks (RECOPE). The networks continued awareness raising of local communities on child rights and protection, reaching a total of 29,981 individuals. Psychosocial assistance was provided to 11,871 conflict affected children (5,342 girls) through Child Friendly Spaces.
In Somalia, 562 children (28 girls) were released and provided with services, among which 82% formerly associated with Al Shabab. Due to increased vulnerability from conflict and COVID-19, families experienced loss of household income which led to harmful coping mechanisms with risk of child recruitment. As a preventative measure, 121 at-risk children (72 girls) from low-income families benefited from community-based services. Children were also provided with psychosocial support through dedicated training of social workers on mindfulness and wellbeing through the Elman Foundation and Waves of Change.
In South Sudan, 44 children (3 girls) were released and provided with support in collaboration with the NDDRC and Ministry of Gender Child and Social Welfare. An additional 13 boys were spontaneously released and/or escaped and self-reunified with their families. Continued support is provided to the 633 children (167 girls) released in previous years through UNICEFs three-year reintegration programme.
4. Output four supports research and data collection to develop new evidence of programme impact, root causes that can inform programming and strengthened monitoring and reporting to prevent and end child recruitment and use. In CAR, the M&R mechanisms were strengthened with a total of 1016 incidents affecting 837 children (445 girls) reported and verified. UNICEF also made plans to undertake a formative evaluation to guide decisions and the selection of programming in CAR. Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, this was postponed to 2021.
In Somalia, preparations were made to undertake a study into the drivers of child recruitment by Al Shabab in 2021. MRM continued demonstrating the deteriorating situation of children in Somalia with evidence of increasing sexual violence and rape during 2020. In South Sudan, the MRM was instrumental in advocating for the revision and signing of the action plan on ending all six grave violations in February 2020. The CTFMR verified 152 violations against 146 children (30 girls), indicating an 8% decrease compared to 2019.
This output also includes continued work with UNU in the project called Managing Exits from Armed Conflict at UNICEF HQ-level. In light of the 25th Anniversary of the Graca Machel report on the Impact of Armed Conflict on Children, UNICEF in 2020 began compiling and conducting a comprehensive review of the 15 years of data gathered by the MRM and published in the Secretary Generals reports. An analysis on findings and the impact of various measures on accountability for violations is estimated to be released in 2021.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
